children.definition: An end joint made up of several meshing wedges or fingers of wood bonded together with an adhesive. Fingers are sloped and may be cut parallel to either the wide or narrow face of the piece.

children.label: laminated veneer lumber
children.definition: An engineered wood product created by parallel lamination of veneers glued under heat and pressure with the grain of each veneer running parallel to the longitudinal axis of the billet.

children.label: wood trusses
children.definition: An assembly of members, such as beams, bars, rods, and the like, so combined as to form a rigid framework. All members are interconnected to form triangles.

children.label: glulam
children.definition: A manufactured structural timber product composed of layers of dimensional lumber glued together.

children.label: palm oils
children.definition: Oils pressed from the pulp of the fruit of various palms (Arecaceae). The African palm (Elaeis guineensis) is a common source for palm oil. Palm oils are high in saturated fat and carotene, and used in foods, soaps, cosmetics, candles. Compare with palm kernel oil.

children.label: virgin olive oil
children.definition: A grade of olive oil indicating oil processed without any chemical treatment and containing no additives.

children.label: lampante olive oil
children.definition: A nonedible oil derived from olive fruit and is used for industrial purposes.

children.label: babassu oil
children.definition: The oil extracted from kernels (seeds) of the babassu palm, Attalea speciosa. The oil is used in food, cosmetics and soaps, having properties similar to coconut oil.

children.label: palm kernel oil
children.definition: The oil from the kernel or "nut" of the palm. Compare with palm oils.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: mango butter
children.definition: A natural fat extracted from kernels of the mango.

children.label: agronomy
children.definition: The science of crop production and soil management.

children.label: plant viruses
children.definition: Viruses that infect plant hosts.

children.label: girdling
children.definition: Injury resulting from removal or tight encircling of the bark or cambium around the outer circumference of a plant stem or tree trunk, which may cause death by disrupting nutrient transport.

children.label: lodging
children.definition: The condition of a plant, especially a cereal, that has been flattened in the field or damaged so that it cannot stand upright by weather conditions or because the stem is not strong enough to support the plant.

children.label: snow damage
children.definition: Damage to plants from snow.

children.label: bitter pit
children.definition: Pits developing on apple fruits which result in a bitter tasting apple. The cause is due to a deficiency of calcium and/or an excess of potassium or magnesium within the apple fruit itself, and not necessarily due to soil fertility or whole plant nutrient status.

children.label: oleocellosis
children.definition: A physiological disorder in citrus fruits that is caused by the release of phytotoxic oils from the ruptured rind (peel) oil glands, causing injury and spotting to the peel.

children.label: bacterial wilt
children.definition: A plant disease caused by bacteria which causes wilting and shriveling of the stems and leaves.

children.label: Verticillium wilt
children.definition: A plant disease caused by fungi of the genus Verticillium, which results in the shriveling, drooping, and browning of plant parts.

children.label: Fusarium wilt
children.definition: A disease of plants caused by fungi of the genus Fusarium.

children.label: gummosis
children.definition: The exudation of gum, latex or sap from some fruit trees and sugar cane, which may be caused by insects, mechanical damage, disease microorganisms or unfavorable weather.

children.label: foot rot (plant)
children.definition: A disease of plants in which the stem or trunk rots near the ground.

children.label: internal browning
children.definition: Internal browning is a low-temperature storage disorder of some fruits/vegetables which develops when they are stored at or just below freezing temperature.

children.label: weather fleck
children.definition: Weather fleck is a non-infectious disease, induced by air-pollution (mainly ozone), and characterized by small necrotic lesions on the leaves. These lesions are usually dark brown in color in the beginning and gradually transition to white color over time as leaf tissue dies.

children.label: replant disease
children.definition: A disease affecting susceptible plants such as apples, pears, plums, cherries and roses when they are placed into soil previously occupied by a related species. The exact causes are not known, but in the first year the new plants will grow poorly. One theory is that replant disease is due to a whole menagerie of tree pathogens - fungi, bacteria, nematodes, viruses and other organisms.

children.label: fruit cracking
children.definition: A physiological disorder common in many fruit crops, especially tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum). The pericarp, or skin, of the fruit develops cracks mainly because the fruit contents absorb water faster than the expansion of the fruit wall.

children.label: downy mildew
children.definition: A pseudofungus forming grayish downy patches, usually on the underside of leaves.

children.label: forest decline
children.definition: A complex disorder involving abiotic and biotic stresses on a forest stand that results in a slow, progressive decrease in growth with loss of health and vigor. Mortality is common. However, affected trees may recover once the stresses are removed. Natural factors (hurricanes, floods, fires, drought, pests, etc.) as well as human activity (deforestation and forest degradation) are involved.

children.label: boxwood blight
children.definition: A fungal disease affecting the stems and leaves of species of Buxus.

children.label: Verticillium wilt
children.definition: A plant disease caused by fungi of the genus Verticillium, which results in the shriveling, drooping, and browning of plant parts.

children.label: Fusarium wilt
children.definition: A disease of plants caused by fungi of the genus Fusarium.

children.label: powdery mildew
children.definition: A fungus forming a white powdery coating on leaves and stems.

children.label: hyperhydricity
children.definition: A physiological disorder occurring in plant tissue cultures characterized by high water retention capacity due to adverse culture conditions.

children.label: phyllody
children.definition: Abnormal development of floral parts into leaf-like structures.

children.label: rhizomania
children.definition: Abnormal root development in plants, especially seen in sugar beet, where it is caused by the Beet Necrotic Yellow Vein Virus (BNYVV).

children.label: aster yellows
children.definition: A disease of various plants, caused by phytoplasmas transmitted by leafhoppers, resulting in dwarfing and yellowing of the plant.

children.label: lethal yellowing
children.definition: A fatal disease of coconut and other palms. It has swept through the coconut-growing regions of Jamaica, Cuba, the Cayman Islands, and Florida, and is presently destroying palms in the Yucatan. The disease is caused by phytoplasmas and is spread by plant-sucking insects called plant-hoppers. The first visible sign is the dropping of all fruit; this is followed by the withering of new flowers, and yellowing leaves. There is no effective cure; trees die within 3-6 months after appearance of the first symptoms.

children.label: bacterial wilt
children.definition: A plant disease caused by bacteria which causes wilting and shriveling of the stems and leaves.

children.label: plant pests
children.definition: Organisms that may directly or indirectly cause disease, spoilage, or damage to plants, plant parts or processed plant materials. Common examples include certain insects, mites, nematodes, fungi, molds, viruses, and bacteria.

children.label: head blight
children.definition: Chlorotic symptoms affecting the inflorescences or seed heads of cereal crops.

children.label: epinasty
children.definition: Stronger growth on the upper surface than on the under surface of a plant part, which causes the part, such as a leaf, to curl downward.

children.label: embolism
children.definition: Blocking of a blood vessel by an embolus which can be a blood clot or other undissolved material in the blood stream.

children.label: hypoxia
children.definition: Relatively complete absence of oxygen in one or more tissues.

children.label: hyponasty
children.definition: Stronger growth on the lower surface than on the upper surface of a plant part, which causes the part, such as a leaf, to curl upward.

children.label: leaf density
children.definition: It is defined as the ratio of leaf dry weight to leaf volume. It is calculated by dividing specific leaf weight by leaf thickness.

children.label: leaf reflectance
children.definition: Leaf reflectance is defined as the proportion of the irradiated light that is reflected by the leaf.

children.label: serotiny
children.definition: An ecological adaptation in which some seeds are retained in long-closed cones within the plant canopy for a year or more and are released only in response to an environmental trigger, e.g., wildfires.

children.label: crop production
children.definition: Industries in the Crop Production subsector grow crops mainly for food and fiber. The subsector comprises establishments, such as farms, orchards, groves, greenhouses, and nurseries, primarily engaged in growing crops, plants, vines, or trees and their seeds.

children.label: crop year
children.definition: The year in which a crop is produced and harvested. Compare "marketing year."

children.label: yield components
children.definition: Plant parts contributing to yield based on their number, size and weight.

children.label: lint yield
children.definition: The quantity of cotton fiber produced per unit of land.

children.label: plasticulture
children.definition: The use of plastics in crop production and cultivation protection, including plastic film mulches, row covers, tunnels, and greenhouses.

children.label: greenhouse production
children.definition: production of crops in a greenhouse structure.

children.label: transplant production
children.definition: production of plants by seed, cuttings or other propagation methods intended to be sold and/or used as transplants.

children.label: aquatic plant culture
children.definition: The cultivation of aquatic plants for food or other purposes.

children.label: culling (plants)
children.definition: The individual removal of genetically undesirable, inferior, weak, diseased or infested plants from a planting in order to ensure the level of genetic purity or vigor of the crop.

children.label: thinning (plants)
children.definition: The practice of reducing the number of plants in an area or the quantity of vegetative or reproductive structures on individual plants.

children.label: forest thinning
children.definition: The silvicultural practice of removing excess, diseased or poor quality trees and underbrush to improve the growth, health and value of the standing timber crop.

children.label: deblossoming
children.definition: The practice of removing flowers from plants. Deblossoming is done on fruit trees in order to increase the size and quality of the fruit crop.

children.label: sodding
children.definition: The placement and establishment of sod strips to cover bare soil areas.

children.label: winter sowing method
children.definition: A propagation method used throughout the winter where temperate climate seeds are sown into protective vented containers and placed outdoors to foster a naturally timed, high percentage germination of climate tolerant seedlings.

children.label: propagation materials
children.definition: A plant part such as a bud, tuber, root, or shoot used to reproduce (propagate) an individual plant vegetatively.

children.label: seed tubers
children.definition: Tubers that are typically cut for asexual propagation.

children.label: softwood cuttings
children.definition: Cuttings prepared from the soft, succulent, non-lignified or new growth of woody plants, mostly during spring season before the wood begins to harden.

children.label: corms
children.definition: A solid, short, swollen underground stem which serves as an asexual propagule for the plant, lasts only one year, and bears the next year's growth at the top of the old corm.

children.label: grass sprigs
children.definition: A portion of a stem and root of grass, used for transplanting and the establishment of turf and lawns.

children.label: seed exchange
children.definition: Any act of giving and receiving seeds, usually with no exchange of money.

children.label: deadheading
children.definition: The practice of removing dead or spent flowers to encourage subsequent flowering, prevent seed production or to improve the plant's appearance.

children.label: hydroponics
children.definition: The growing of plants in a soilless environment where nutrients are provided by the application of nutrient solutions.

children.label: aeroponics
children.definition: The growing of plants in a soilless environment where nutrients are intermittently or continuously misted on to the plant roots.

children.label: training (plants)
children.definition: Physical manipulation of plant growth and structure in a particular way so that plants perform better. It includes different agricultural practices, such as staking, plant topping and pruning.

children.label: vernalization
children.definition: The treatment of seeds, seedlings, bulbs, or other parts of a plant to cold conditions in order to shorten the vegetative period and promote flowering.

children.label: fertigation
children.definition: Application of appropriate amount of fertilizers (dissolved form or suspended form) to the plants via irrigation water or through irrigation systems.

children.label: seed dressings
children.definition: The process of coating seeds with clay, biofertilizers, pesticides or other inert materials to give them a uniform shape and increasing their size and weight for improved visibility, plantability, germination and resistance to diseases.

children.label: seed stratification
children.definition: The practice of placing seeds in moist media and specific temperature regimes in order to break seed dormancy and promote germination.

children.label: seed priming
children.definition: Pretreatment of seeds by various methods in order to improve seed germination rate, percentage germination, and improve uniformity of seedling emergence by controlling the water available in the seed. The pretreatment initiates the early stages of germination, but does not permit radicle protrusion, and then the seeds are dried until needed.

children.label: seed scarification
children.definition: Pregerminative treatment to make seed coats permeable to water and gases; accomplished usually by mechanical abrasion or by soaking seeds briefly in a strong acid or other chemical solution.

children.label: top dressings
children.definition: The application of compost or fertilizer on top of the soil during plant growth.

children.label: topping (pruning)
children.definition: The practice of removing the top branches of a tree or shrub.

children.label: hedging (pruning)
children.definition: A specialized form of mechanical pruning done in orchards that involves cutting back the sides of the tree canopy to reduce crowding between rows of trees, improve equipment access, improve air circulation and light penetration, and delay the need for tree thinning.

children.label: chemical pruning
children.definition: The application of agricultural chemicals to remove the quantity of vegetative or reproductive plant parts on an individual plant in order to alter the shape, growth pattern, flowering or fruiting of a plant.

children.label: weed hosts
children.definition: Weeds which serve as hosts for pests and pathogens.

children.label: noxious weeds
children.definition: A weed arbitrarily defined by laws as being especially undesirable. The definition of this term will vary according to legal interpretations.

children.label: pomace
children.definition: The pulpy residue remaining after the juice has been pressed from fruit.

children.label: thatch
children.definition: A layer of dead grass in a stand of grass.

children.label: wood shavings
children.definition: A small wood particle of indefinite dimensions developed incidental to certain woodworking operations involving rotary cutterheads usually turning in the direction of the grain. This cutting action produces a thin chip of varying thickness, usually feathered along at least one edge and thick at another and generally curled.

children.label: waste wood
children.definition: Pieces of wood, such as branches, limbs, and wood scrap, leftover from wood harvesting, wood processing or leftover from construction projects.

children.label: crop residues
children.definition: Any organic matter left in the field after the harvest of a crop, e.g. leaves, stalks, stubble, roots, hulls.

children.label: sugarcane trash
children.definition: The dried leaves that are left over in the field after the sugarcane is harvested. Farmers usually burn the trash since it resists biodegradation, is highly indigestible as fodder, has a low density biomass and is bulky to transport.

children.label: pecan husks
children.definition: The green fleshy tissue that covers and encases the developing pecan nut.

children.label: almond shells
children.definition: The hard layer between the almond hull and the almond meat.

children.label: almond hulls
children.definition: The outermost green fleshy tissue of developing almond nut that later dries up and either falls on its own or removed mechanically. Once hulls are removed, almond shell is seen.

children.label: cropping systems
children.definition: The pattern of crops grown on a given piece of land, or order in which the crops are cultivated over a fixed period.

children.label: mixed cropping
children.definition: The growing of several crops simultaneously in the same field but not in rows.

children.label: sequential cropping
children.definition: The growing of two or more crops in sequence on the same field in the same year.

children.label: intercropping
children.definition: Any pattern of planting a plant in or near other plants.

children.label: alley cropping
children.definition: A cropping system that involves growing crops in a wide strip, typically 6 meters in width, between lines of closely planted, fast-growing trees or shrubs. These woody species are usually leguminous and are pruned frequently to provide a mulching material and nutrients to the crop in the alley.

children.label: relay cropping
children.definition: The seeding of one crop into another standing crop, e.g., winter wheat into standing soybeans. A practice of starting one crop in another.

children.label: strip cropping
children.definition: The growing of crops in a systematic arrangement of strips or bands which serve as vegetative barriers to wind and water erosion. The strips or bands may run perpendicular to the slope of the land or to the direction of prevailing winds.

children.label: crop rotation
children.definition: System of cultivation where different crops are planted in consecutive growing seasons to maintain soil fertility.

children.label: double cropping
children.definition: Two different crops grown on the same area in one growing season.

children.label: sole cropping
children.definition: Growing one crop variety in pure stands on a piece of land at any one time.

children.label: ratooning
children.definition: Production of a subsequent crop that results from the regrowth from roots of the previous harvested crop, as in sugarcane, pineapple, and banana.

children.label: bioenergy cropping
children.definition: Growing crops for the production of bio-fuels.

children.label: continuous cropping
children.definition: The growing of a single crop species on a field year after year. Contrast crop rotation and mixed cropping.

children.label: plus trees
children.definition: A tree which in its outward appearance (phenotype) is superior to the average tree of the same species grown at a similar site. Visibly superior characteristics may include morphology, vigor, pest or disease resistance, growth, etc., but these characteristics have not been clonally or progeny tested.

children.label: nitrogen-fixing trees
children.definition: Trees that can convert atmospheric nitrogen into usable form through a symbiotic relationship with bacteria that live in root nodules; they have many uses in agroforestry including mulch, nitrogen fertilizer, food and fodder.

children.label: saplings
children.definition: A young tree that is more mature than a seedling but is not yet seed-producing. A silvicultural tree class in which size limits vary by region but is generally accepted as 2-4 inches in diameter and 4 to 4-1/2 feet in height in the United States.

children.label: street trees
children.definition: A tree planted along a street to provide shade or for ornamental purposes.

children.label: elite trees
children.definition: A tree which is greatly superior to the average tree of the same species in some inherited characteristics as determined by progeny tests.

children.label: seed trees
children.definition: Trees that produce seeds; usually a superior tree left standing at the time of cutting to produced seeds for reforestation.

children.label: mangroves (trees)
children.definition: Tropical trees, or deciduous conifers, or shrubs which produce many prop roots and grow in swamps, coastal saline or brackish water.

children.label: shade trees
children.definition: A tall tree which provides shade at ground level due to its large canopy.

children.label: ornamental trees
children.definition: A tree cultivated for its beauty rather than for use. It is usually a small flowering tree used for understory or massed in the open for color and texture.

children.label: hazard trees
children.definition: A tree with structural defects likely to cause failure of all or part of the tree and with high potential to cause injury, loss of life or property damage.

children.label: retained trees
children.definition: Trees and saplings that were saved from destruction because of their value or use in agricultural land.

children.label: host plants
children.definition: Plants which provide shelter, habitat, breeding sites or serve as a food source as part of the life cycle of another organism.

children.label: topiary
children.definition: Plants that have been trimmed or clipped into decorative shapes.

children.label: xerophytes
children.definition: Plants that have adapted for life with a limited supply of water.

children.label: nurse plants
children.definition: Plants that provide shelter for younger or more valuable trees, crops or other plants by protecting them from damage by frost, wind, sunlight, predators, pests, etc.

children.label: long-day plants
children.definition: A plant that requires a long period of light (day time) to flower. They usually flower when day length or light period is more than about twelve hours.

children.label: calcifuges
children.definition: Plants that thrive in acid soils and that do not thrive in lime-rich, calcareous, or alkaline soils.

children.label: weed hosts
children.definition: Weeds which serve as hosts for pests and pathogens.

children.label: noxious weeds
children.definition: A weed arbitrarily defined by laws as being especially undesirable. The definition of this term will vary according to legal interpretations.

children.label: hemicryptophytes
children.definition: One of Raunkiaer's life-form categories, being a plant whose perennating buds or shoot apices are borne at the ground level.

children.label: phreatophytes
children.definition: Deep-rooted plants whose roots extend into or below the capillary zone to obtain water from the water table.

children.label: gametophytes
children.definition: A phase where sexual organs are produced and bear gametes in the life cycle of organisms having alternation of generations (i.e., having two or more forms in the life cycle). Compare sporophytes.

children.label: insectary plants
children.definition: An insectary plant is a flowering plant which attracts and possibly maintains, with its nectar and pollen resources, a population of natural enemies which contribute to biological pest management on crops.

children.label: vines
children.definition: Woody or herbaceous plants which produce flexible stems that climb, trail, or creep. Vines may lie prostrate on the ground or have tendrils, twining stems, or other mechanisms to cling to natural and manmade structures.

children.label: broadleaved evergreens
children.definition: A plant that retains its leaves in the fall (in contrast to deciduous plants) and is not a needle-type conifer.

children.label: short-day plants
children.definition: A plant that requires a long period of darkness (night time) to flower. They usually flower when day length or light period is less than about twelve hours.

children.label: cisgenic plants
children.definition: A cisgenic plant contains one or more genes, from either the same species or from a different species, that are sexually compatible.

children.label: transgenic plants
children.definition: A transgenic plant contains one or more genes from other species of plants. These genes usually add some special character or function to the plant.

children.label: day-neutral plants
children.definition: A day-neutral plant is one whose flowering is not dependent upon the duration of light or dark period as seen in long-day or short-day plants.

children.label: C3 plants
children.definition: Plants in which the CO2 is initially fixed by the Calvin cycle in photosynthesis.

children.label: vascular plants
children.definition: Plants containing specialized vascular tissue (xylem and phloem) which are more highly evolved than such bryophytes as mosses and liverworts. Vascular plants include ferns, gymnosperms, and angiosperms.

children.label: phanerophytes
children.definition: One of Raunkiaer's life-form categories, being a plant whose perennating buds are borne on branches that are 25 cm above the soil level.

children.label: volunteer plants
children.definition: Plants found growing without having been planted, as by natural regeneration, and if undesired, are considered weeds. In crop rotation fields, volunteers from the previous year's crop may germinate and establish in the current crop; these "crop plants as weeds" or "rogue" plants may require control measures.

children.label: seedlings
children.definition: A tree grown from seed that has not yet reached a height of 0.9 m (3 ft) or exceeded 5.1 cm (2 in) in diameter at breast height, which would qualify it as a sapling.

children.label: graminoids
children.definition: Grasses and other grass-like plants such as sedges and rushes are collectively known as graminoids.

children.label: aquatic plants
children.definition: Plants that grow in water either floating on the surface, growing up from the bottom of the body of water or growing under the surface of the water.

children.label: macrophytes
children.definition: Aquatic plants that are macroscopic (easily seen by the naked eye) and can be emergent, floating or submerged.

children.label: submerged aquatic plants
children.definition: Aquatic plants with leaves at or below the water surface.

children.label: emergent plants
children.definition: Aquatic plants which have their upper structures (e.g. leaves, stems or inflorescences) extended out of the water.

children.label: free-floating plants
children.definition: Aquatic plants that float on the water surface and are not rooted in soil.

children.label: phytoplankton
children.definition: Free-floating, mainly microscopic, photosynthetic organisms, such as algae, dinoflagellates, and diatoms, in aquatic systems.

children.label: ground cover plants
children.definition: Plants that are low-growing, form a dense mat of foliage, and spread easily by stolons, runners or rhizomes.

children.label: calcicoles
children.definition: Plants that thrive in lime-rich, alkaline, or calcareous soils, and do not thrive in acid soils.

children.label: oilseed crops
children.definition: Primarily soybeans, and other crops such as peanuts, cottonseed, sunflower seed, flaxseed, safflower seed, rapeseed, sesame seed, castor beans, canola, rapeseed, and mustard seeds used to produce edible and/or inedible oils, as well as high-protein animal meal.

children.label: cryptogams
children.definition: Plants and plant-like organisms, such as mosses, ferns, fungi, and algae, that reproduce by spores and not by seeds.

children.label: non-vascular plants
children.definition: Plants, such as mosses, liverworts, and hornworts, which do not contain the specialized vascular tissue (xylem and phloem) such as is found in the ferns, gymnosperms, and angiosperms.

children.label: wetland plants
children.definition: Plants adapted for survival in soils frequently saturated with surface or groundwater.

children.label: salt marsh plants
children.definition: Plants that grow in salt marshes and are salt tolerant as well as tolerant of wet conditions.

children.label: chasmophytes
children.definition: Plants rooted in clefts or crevices of rocks, that are filled with soil or organic matter.

children.label: browse plants
children.definition: Woody plants (shrubs or low trees) whose leaves and young stems are eaten in the field by animals.

children.label: scions
children.definition: An aerial plant part, often a branchlet, that is grafted onto the root-bearing part of another plant.

children.label: crops
children.definition: USDA considers crops to be those plants that are cultivated either for sale or for subsistence.

children.label: cash crops
children.definition: An agricultural crop grown to provide revenue from an off-farm source.

children.label: catch crops
children.definition: A quick growing crop, planted and harvested between two regular crops.

children.label: trap crops
children.definition: A plant that in interspersed in a crop or planted near a crop as a decoy for the purpose of attracting harmful insects away from the crop, providing a pesticide free solution.

children.label: forage crops
children.definition: Annual or perennial crops grown primarily to provide feed for livestock. During harvesting operations, most of the aboveground portion of the plant is removed from the field and processed for later feeding.

children.label: grain crops
children.definition: Crops, mostly grass crops, that are grown for their edible seeds, such as corn, wheat, rye, buckwheat, amaranth, and etc. Grain markets include soybeans as grains.

children.label: companion crops
children.definition: Crops that are compatible with each other and grow well together. Companion crops are grown at the same time on the same land, especially if one provides a benefit to the other.

children.label: specialty crops
children.definition: Fruits and vegetables, tree nuts, dried fruits, horticulture, and nursery crops (including floriculture). Wild plants are not considered specialty crops even though they may be used for the same purpose as cultivated plants. However, natural populations of native plants that are brought into cultivation, such as sugar maple trees, pecans, blueberry, huckleberry and cranberry are considered specialty crops by USDA.

children.label: horticultural crops
children.definition: Horticulture crops are crops that are used by people for food, for medicinal purposes, and for aesthetic gratification.

children.label: industrial crops
children.definition: Those crops that are not specifically grown for foodstuffs (such as fruit crops, vegetable crops and grain crops), but are specifically grown to yield a useful product for man or industrial processes, such as fiber, oils, rubber, chemicals, resions, energy, waxes, or dyes.

children.label: energy crops
children.definition: Crops grown specifically to provide the raw materials for energy production, including food crops such as corn and sugarcane and nonfood crops such as poplar trees and switchgrass.

children.label: green manures
children.definition: Crops grown to be incorporated into the soil to increase soil quality, fertility and structure.

children.label: cover crops
children.definition: A crop grown between periods of regular production of the main crop for the purposes of protecting the soil from erosion and improving soil productivity, health and quality.

children.label: alternative crops
children.definition: An agronomic crop that is not usually grown in a particular region, but planted due to its high market value or some other benefit. These crops are generally suitable for small scale farming by limited-resource farmers and small landowners.

children.label: forbs
children.definition: Broad-leaved herbaceous plants, especially those growing in a field or prairie, as opposed to mosses, ferns, or grasses.

children.label: hyperaccumulators
children.definition: Plants with the ability to accumulate high concentrations of heavy metals without toxic effects and are used in phytoremediation of contaminated soils.

children.label: epiphytes
children.definition: Nonparasitic plants that grow on other plants for support, rather than rooting in the soil.

children.label: chamaephytes
children.definition: One of Raunkiaer's life-form categories, woody plants whose perennating buds are borne close to the ground, no more than 25 cm above the soil level.

children.label: plantlets
children.definition: Young plants or small plants, usually vegetatively produced from a parent.

children.label: C4 plants
children.definition: Plants where the initial carbon fixation occurs in the outer mesophyll cells, and the Calvin cycle occurs in the inner bundle sheath cells.

children.label: medical botany
children.definition: The study and use of plants or plant-derived chemicals in treating or preventing diseases.

children.label: dendrology
children.definition: The identification, systematic classification, and study of habits and distribution of forest trees and other woody plants.

children.label: photosynthates
children.definition: The resulting chemical products of photosynthesis.

children.label: phytosiderophores
children.definition: Chelating compounds in plants, common in grasses, that sequester iron.

children.label: phycobilin
children.definition: A water-soluble proteinaceous pigment that aids photosynthesis and is found in red algae and cyanobacteria.

children.label: phytochrome
children.definition: A bluish conjugated plant pigment protein that exists in two forms, Pr and Pfr, that absorbs red light and then initiates physiological responses such as germination, growth and flowering.

children.label: betalains
children.definition: Compounds derived from tyrosine via betalamic acid, including betaxanthins and betacyanins. They are found in the Caryophyllales order of plants and some Basidiomycetes.

children.label: xanthophylls
children.definition: Oxygenated forms of carotenoids. They are usually derived from alpha and beta carotene.

children.label: phytopharmaceuticals
children.definition: Any non-mineral, non-vitaminic, bioactive plant constituent that researchers regard as possibly useful in health promotion or in the prevention or treatment of disease.

children.label: essential oils
children.definition: Volatile oils in aromatic plants which give the characteristic odor or flavor to the plant. Often used in fragrances and flavorings.

children.label: plant hormones
children.definition: Any of the chemical substances produced in a plant in minute quantities which affect physiological processes, growth and development.

children.label: indole butyric acid
children.definition: A synthetic auxin widely used in horticulture to induce rooting of cuttings.

children.label: karrikins
children.definition: Karrikin was originally isolated from the smoke of bush fires in Australia. This smoke-derived compound helps in seed germination and early plant development. Structurally, it belongs to the butenolide family.

children.label: auxins
children.definition: A natural or synthetic phytohormone that regulates plant growth and development.

children.label: indole butyric acid
children.definition: A synthetic auxin widely used in horticulture to induce rooting of cuttings.

children.label: cytokinins
children.definition: A class of phytohormones that promote and control growth responses of plants.

children.label: gibberellins
children.definition: A plant hormone useful in regulating the growth characteristics of many plants.

children.label: phytonutrients
children.definition: Bioactive plant-derived chemicals that are associated with beneficial health effects.

children.label: radiation use efficiency
children.definition: A measurement that relates dry matter production to the photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) energy that is intercepted.

children.label: dehiscence
children.definition: The splitting open at maturity of pods of capsules along definite lines or sutures.

children.label: nutation
children.definition: Movement of plant parts caused by irregular growth, such as the circular movement detected in growing seedlings and the "searching" movement of growing young tendrils.

children.label: nastic movement
children.definition: The movement of plant parts in response to non-directional stimuli. The stimulus may be external, such as the movement of Mimosa leaves when touch (thigmonasty), or internal, such as the sudden movement of plant parts due to changes in turgor pressure (seismonasty). Nyctinasty is the movement of organs, such as the opening of flowers during the day and closing at night, in response to the diurnal cycle.

children.label: apomixis
children.definition: Biological reproduction without fertilization, meiosis, or production of gametes, resulting in seeds that are genetically identical to the parent plant.

children.label: pollination
children.definition: The transfer of pollen grains (male gametes) to the plant ovule (female gamete).

children.label: self-pollination
children.definition: The pollination of an individual or biotype with its own pollen, the offspring being termed selfs.

children.label: insect pollination
children.definition: Pollination of flowers by insects.

children.label: fly pollination
children.definition: Pollination of flowers by flies.

children.label: bee pollination
children.definition: Pollination of flowers by bees.

children.label: bird pollination
children.definition: Pollination of flowers by bird species.

children.label: pollen flow
children.definition: Natural movement of pollen from one place, or an organism to another.

children.label: cross pollination
children.definition: Fertilization of a plant with pollen from another plant. Pollen may be transferred by wind, insects, other organisms, or humans.

children.label: epinasty
children.definition: Stronger growth on the upper surface than on the under surface of a plant part, which causes the part, such as a leaf, to curl downward.

children.label: budbreak
children.definition: The start of growth from a bud.

children.label: lammas growth
children.definition: Abnormal late season growth of terminals or buds.

children.label: biennials
children.definition: A plant that lives for two years, producing vegetative growth the first year, usually blooming and fruiting in the second year, and then dying.

children.label: indeterminate growth
children.definition: Plant growth that continues at the apex, or tip, such as the continued flower development in indeterminate inflorescences.

children.label: geophytes
children.definition: A perennial plant whose perennating buds are found under the soil, usually attached to a tuber, bulb, rhizome etc.

children.label: krummholz
children.definition: The stunted growth habit, literally crooked wood, caused by wind and found in certain tree species at their upper limit of distribution.

children.label: monocarpic plants
children.definition: Monocarpic plant flowers and produces seed only once in its lifetime.

children.label: determinate growth
children.definition: Plant growth in which the growth of the main axis is terminated. Typically applied to inflorescences, where the terminal flower is the first to mature along the inflorescence.

children.label: hyponasty
children.definition: Stronger growth on the lower surface than on the upper surface of a plant part, which causes the part, such as a leaf, to curl upward.

children.label: root shoot ratio
children.definition: The ratio of roots to shoots in a plant, either measured by dry weight or fresh weight.

children.label: translocation (plant physiology)
children.definition: The transport of dissolved material within a plant from one part of the plant to another.

children.label: transpiration
children.definition: Water discharged into the atmosphere from plant surfaces.

children.label: crop coefficient
children.definition: An estimate of consumptive water use by crops based on evapotranspiration values.

children.label: harmomegathy
children.definition: Harmomegathy is the process by which pollen grains and spores change in shape to accommodate variations in the volume of the cytoplasm caused by cells changing hydration.

children.label: leaf relative water content
children.definition: It is the actual leaf water content relative to the water content of leaf at full turgescence. It is used to assess the water status of the leaf, plant, etc.

children.label: water use efficiency
children.definition: A characteristic of plants which is measured by the amount of dry matter or harvestable product produced per unit of water used by the plant.

children.label: abortion (plants)
children.definition: Premature termination of the development of pollen, gametes, embryos, seeds, fruits, flowers etc.

children.label: vivipary (plants)
children.definition: Plants having seeds or bulbils that germinate while still attached to the parent plant, e.g. mangrove, Allium.

children.label: pollen germination
children.definition: Plant pollen grain changes from hydration until the appearance of the pollen tube.

children.label: natural pruning
children.definition: The natural dying and breaking off of the lower branches of trees due to shading from the upper canopy.

children.label: leaf venation
children.definition: The distribution and arrangement pattern of veins system in a leaf.

children.label: vernation
children.definition: The mode of arrangement of young leaves and its parts in the bud, before unfolding.

children.label: endozoochory
children.definition: The dispersal of plant seeds or spores through ingestion by animals and subsequently dropping it through their feces.

children.label: myrmecochory
children.definition: Seed or spore dispersal by ants. Ants use their appendages/elaiosomes to attach to the seeds.

children.label: epizoochory
children.definition: The dispersal of plant seeds or spores accidentally attached on the external body of an animal. Dispersal of seeds/spores through the mouth is also considered epizoochory.

children.label: anemochory
children.definition: Dispersal of seed by wind.

children.label: hydrochory
children.definition: The dispersal of seeds or spores by water.

children.label: autochory
children.definition: The process of seeds and fruits dispersal by means of some kind of explosive physical expulsion. The fruit "explodes", propelling its seeds some distance to the ground surrounding the parent plant; also called "discharge dispersal".

children.label: etiolation
children.definition: Plant growth exhibiting pale or bleached color due to the deprivation of light.

children.label: booting stage
children.definition: Growth stage when a grass seedhead is enclosed by the sheath of the uppermost (flag) leaf.

children.label: flowering
children.definition: The time at which a flower comes into full bloom.

children.label: xylem
children.definition: A vascular plant tissue that conducts water and minerals salts from the roots to the leaves.

children.label: growth rings
children.definition: The layer of wood growth put on a tree during a single growing season. In the temperate zone, the annual growth rings of many species (e.g., oaks and pines) are readily distinguished because of the differences in the cells formed during the early and late parts of the season. In some temperate zone species (e.g., black gum and sweetgum) and many tropical species, annual growth rings are not easily recognized.

children.label: earlywood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed during the early part of the growing season. It is usually less dense and weaker mechanically than latewood.

children.label: latewood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed after the earlywood formation has ceased. It is usually denser and stronger mechanically than earlywood.

children.label: reaction wood
children.definition: Wood with more or less distinctive anatomical characters, formed typically in parts of leaning or crooked stems and in branches. In hardwoods, this consists of tension wood, and in softwoods, compression wood.

children.label: tension wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood found in leaning trees of some hardwood species and characterized by the presence of gelatinous fibers and excessive longitudinal shrinkage. Tension wood may cause warping.

children.label: compression wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood formed on the lower side of branches and inclined trunks of softwood trees. Compression wood shrinks excessively longitudinally, compared with normal wood.

children.label: heartwood
children.definition: The wood extending from the pith to the sapwood, the cells of which no longer participate in the life processes of the tree. Heartwood may contain phenolic compounds, gums, resins, and other materials that usually make it darker and more decay resistant than sapwood.

children.label: juvenile wood
children.definition: Inner core of xylem surrounding the pith. The cells are smaller and less structurally developed than those of the outer xylem. The time during which juvenile wood is formed is termed the juvenile phase.

children.label: sapwood
children.definition: The wood of pale color near the outside of the log. Under most conditions, the sapwood is more susceptible to decay than heartwood.

children.label: tyloses
children.definition: Masses of parenchyma cells appearing somewhat like froth in the pores of some hardwoods, notably the white oaks and black locust. Tyloses are formed by the extension of the cell wall of the living cells surrounding vessels of hardwood.

children.label: xylem vessels
children.definition: Wood cells in hardwoods of comparatively large diameter that have open ends and are set one above the other to form continuous tubes called vessels. The openings of the vessels on the surface of a piece of wood are usually referred to as pores.

children.label: tracheids
children.definition: Tracheids are elongated cells in the xylem, which conduct water and mineral salts in plants. Sometimes referred to as fibers, tracheids are more abundant and longer in length in softwoods than hardwoods. The longer length of softwood tracheids is significant to paper manufacture.

children.label: phloem
children.definition: The tissues of the inner bark, characterized by the presence of sieve tubes and serving for the transport of elaborate foodstuffs.

children.label: compound leaves
children.definition: A compound leaf is a leaf whose lamina/blade is divided into two or more smaller leaflets.

children.label: petioles
children.definition: A leafstalk, whereby the blade of a leaf is attached to the plant stem.

children.label: pulvinus
children.definition: A mass of large thin-walled cells forming a cushionlike swelling at the base of petiole or petiolule and functioning in turgor movements of leaves or leaflets.

children.label: simple leaves
children.definition: A single leaf with one leaf blade or lamina.

children.label: fruits
children.definition: A collective plant structure containing one or more embryos, which as a whole, develops from a gynoecium.

children.label: siliques
children.definition: The peculiar, mostly elongated, 2-valved capsule or pod of the mustard family (Brassicaceae or Cruciferae).

children.label: dehiscent fruits
children.definition: These fruits open at maturity to release the seed, etc.

children.label: syncarp
children.definition: A fleshy, multiple fruit with fused carpels.

children.label: multiple fruit type
children.definition: A fruit from many different flowers which develop closely together to form one fruit (pineapple, mulberry).

children.label: climacteric fruits
children.definition: They are characterized by a rapid increase in the rate of ethylene biosynthesis and respiration at an early stage of ripening. These fruits (tomatoes, bananas, pears, etc.) keep on ripening after harvesting.

children.label: syconia
children.definition: A fleshy fruit with multiple seeds in a hollow compartment, as in the genus Ficus.

children.label: indehiscent fruits
children.definition: Indehiscent fruits do not open to release the seeds and related contents at maturity.

children.label: samaras
children.definition: Dry, one-seeded fruit with a membranous wing.

children.label: caryopsis
children.definition: The fruit of a grass; a grain. The seed and fruit are united, the seed adhering to the thin pericarp, or outer covering of the fruit, throughout.

children.label: acorns
children.definition: The characteristic, 1-celled, 1-seeded fruit of oaks (Quercus spp.); it consists of cuplike part called the cup, cupule, or involucre, and the glands or nut which contains the embryo.

children.label: cypsela
children.definition: A dry, indehiscent, single-seeded fruit that develops from bicarpellary inferior ovary as seen in sunflower fruits.

children.label: achenes
children.definition: A small dry 1-seeded 1-celled indehiscent fruit that develops from superior ovary; as in Plumbaginaceae. Sometimes spelled akene.

children.label: pericarp
children.definition: A wall of a fruit, developed from the ovary or carpel wall.

children.label: mesocarp
children.definition: A portion of plant tissue that is the middle layer of a pericarp.

children.label: exocarp
children.definition: A portion of plant tissue that is the outer layer of a pericarp.

children.label: endocarp
children.definition: A portion of plant tissue that is the innermost differentiated layer of a pericarp.

children.label: schizocarps
children.definition: Literally, splitting fruit. A dry compound fruit, as in the mallow family, splitting up at maturity into several indehiscent 1-seeded carpels (mericarps); the peculiar dry twin-fruit of umbellifer, or parsnip family (cremocarp) is a form of schizocarp.

children.label: aggregate fruits
children.definition: An aggregate fruit is basically a cluster of simple fruits (fruitlets) that are produced from several separate carpels of a single flower, e.g., strawberry, blackberry, etc.

children.label: hesperidium fruits
children.definition: Hesperidium is a modified, septate berry with leathery rind or peel (exocarp, mesocarp). The interior (endocarp) encloses large fleshy, juicy pouches composed of several wedge-shaped sections. Juice pouches or vesicles are outgrowths of endocarp walls.

children.label: trichomes
children.definition: Hair-like extensions on specialized epidermal surfaces of plants which protect against damage from insects, animals, light degradation and fungal infection. Trichomes may also occur on certain unicellular eukaryotes.

children.label: corms
children.definition: A solid, short, swollen underground stem which serves as an asexual propagule for the plant, lasts only one year, and bears the next year's growth at the top of the old corm.

children.label: cladodes
children.definition: Flattened, photosynthetic stems which resemble and function as leaves, such as are found in cacti and asparagus.

children.label: canes
children.definition: Any hollow or pithy woody stems that are strong but flexible, such as bamboos, reeds, rattans, sugar cane, or raspberries.

children.label: primocanes
children.definition: A biennial stem typical of Rubus. In the first year of growth, the stem is called a primocane, since it is not capable of flowering and precedes the floricane. In the second year of growth, the stem is called a floricane, which flowers, bears fruit and dies in this second year.

children.label: floricanes
children.definition: A biennial stem typical of Rubus. In the first year of growth, the stem is called a primocane, since it is not capable of flowering and precedes the floricane. In the second year of growth, the stem is called a floricane, which flowers, bears fruit and dies in this second year.

children.label: symplast
children.definition: The intracellular compartment of a plant consisting of the interconnected cytoplasm of separate cells which are linked by plasmodesmata, in which water and low molecular weight molecules flow between cells.

children.label: tree trunk
children.definition: The main stem of a tree of substantial diameter—roughly, capable of yielding sawtimber, veneer logs, or large poles. Seedlings, saplings, and small-diameter trees have stems, not boles.

children.label: gametophores
children.definition: Structures bearing the reproductive organs (gametangia) of mosses and ferns.

children.label: apoplast
children.definition: The outer compartment of a plant cell external to the plasma membrane. Formed in adjacent cells by the continuum of cell walls, intercellular material and extracellular space, it facilitates the transport of water and solutes.

children.label: adventitious shoots
children.definition: Shoots growing from a part of a plant, such as a leaf, where they are not expected, forming new plants.

children.label: lammas shoots
children.definition: Lammas shoots are shoots that develop by bursting and elongating the current year terminal bud. This will result in 2-0 stock having the appearance of 3-0 stock with the last growth whorl in varying degrees of hardening off. Some of the growth whorls may not be cold hardy.

children.label: proleptic shoots
children.definition: Proleptic shoots are shoots that emerge from the current year's lateral buds while the terminal bud remains dormant.

children.label: fronds
children.definition: The leaf-like structure of a fern, palm, cycad, lichen, seaweed, or other lower plant.

children.label: gynoecium
children.definition: A collective term for the female reproductive structures of a flower.

children.label: inferior ovary
children.definition: An inferior ovary is one that is situated entirely below the point of attachment of the other floral parts in a flower.

children.label: superior ovary
children.definition: A superior ovary is one that is situated entirely above the point of attachment of the other floral parts in a flower.

children.label: nucellus
children.definition: The tissue of an ovule, in which the female gametophyte (embryo sac) develops, the megasporangium.

children.label: pistil
children.definition: The female organs of a flower comprising the ovary, stigma and style.

children.label: styles (flowers)
children.definition: The stalk of a pistil which connects the stigma with the ovary.

children.label: stigma
children.definition: The part of the pistil, usually the tip, often sticky, which receives the pollen and upon which the pollen germinates.

children.label: peduncle
children.definition: A stalk bearing a flower, flower cluster, or a fructification.

children.label: tree crown
children.definition: The branches and foliage of a tree above the main trunk or stem.

children.label: protonemata
children.definition: The filamentous structure which grows following spore germination in mosses, ferns and some liverworts, eventually developing into a mature plant.

children.label: inflorescences
children.definition: The flowering part of a plant, and especially the mode of its arrangement.

children.label: racemose inflorescences
children.definition: The axis of the inflorescence continues to grow and flowers are produced on its lateral sides in an acropetal manner (older flowers at the base and younger flowers towards the top).

children.label: racemes
children.definition: An indeterminate inflorescence in which pedicellate flowers are borne on an unbranched main axis of the inflorescence, lower flowers blossom earlier than the upper flowers.

children.label: catkins
children.definition: A drooping elongated cluster of bracted unisexual flowers found only in woody plants.

children.label: spikes (plant)
children.definition: An indeterminate inflorescence in which sessile flowers are borne directly on the main axis of the inflorescence. Flowers at the bottom blossom earlier than the flowers at the top.

children.label: spadix
children.definition: A type of spike inflorescence with a fleshy or succulent main axis, having small flowers, usually enclosed in a leaf-like spathe.

children.label: spikelets
children.definition: The basic unit of a grass or sedge inflorescence; bearing one or more florets usually subtended by one or two glumes (bracts) on a rachilla. A floret is often surrounded by two scales, one external (lemma), and one internal (palea). They are roughly equivalent to the sepals and petals of the flowers.

children.label: corymbs
children.definition: A flat-topped floral cluster with outer flowers opening first.

children.label: umbels
children.definition: A flower cluster in which stalks (pedicels) of nearly equal length initiates from a common center at the tip of the peduncle, and form a flat or curved umbrella-like shape, characteristic of the Apiaceae/Umbelliferae family.

children.label: bracts
children.definition: A leaflike or scalelike organ subtending a flower or aggregation of flowers ; a modified inflorescence leaf.

children.label: spathes
children.definition: An enlarged, membranous, sheathing bract or bracts subtending an inflorescence, and especially the characteristic bract (often colored) associated with a spadix as the spathe of a jack-in-the-pulpit or calla lily.

children.label: awns
children.definition: A bristle-like appendage, especially on the floral bracts of grasses or on the achenes of composites; the "beards" of wheat, rye etc., are awns.

children.label: hypanthium
children.definition: A floral tube formed by the fusion of the basal portions of the sepals, petals, and stamens, and from which the rest of the floral parts emanate.

children.label: perianth
children.definition: A collective term for the floral envelopes, usually the combined calyx and corolla, or tepals of a flower.

children.label: florets
children.definition: A single flower of a head or cluster, as seen in Compositae.

children.label: disc florets
children.definition: These are small tubular flower located at the centre of the flower head, usually fertile florets as seen in some Asteraceae (sun flower, daisy flower) flowers.

children.label: ray florets
children.definition: Marginal florets surrounding the disk of tubular florets in the flower heads of certain Asteraceae plants. Ray florets are often male flowers with sterile stamens.

children.label: flower tepals
children.definition: Used for outer row of flowers (petals and sepals) when these are not distinguished as either sepals or petals.

children.label: cymose inflorescences
children.definition: When the main axis of an inflorescence ends in a flower.

children.label: lateral roots
children.definition: The roots arising from pericycle cells of other roots.

children.label: second-order lateral roots
children.definition: The roots branching directly from second-order lateral root.

children.label: first-order lateral roots
children.definition: The roots branching directly from a tap root or primary root system.

children.label: root cap
children.definition: A cone-shaped structure in plants made up of a mass of meristematic cells that covers and protects the tip of a growing root. It is the putative site of gravity sensing in plant roots.

children.label: pneumatophores
children.definition: A specialized structure developed from the root in certain plants that grow upward and function as the site of oxygen intake.

children.label: lignotubers
children.definition: A woody swelling at ground level originating from the axils of the cotyledons from whose concealed dormant buds a new tree can develop if the old one is injured. Characteristic of many Eucalypts.

children.label: root crown
children.definition: The growing point where the roots meet the stem.

children.label: resin canals
children.definition: Tubular intercellular spaces lined with resin-secreting cells, common in the wood, bark, and leaves of many gymnosperms and some angiosperms.

children.label: growth rings
children.definition: The layer of wood growth put on a tree during a single growing season. In the temperate zone, the annual growth rings of many species (e.g., oaks and pines) are readily distinguished because of the differences in the cells formed during the early and late parts of the season. In some temperate zone species (e.g., black gum and sweetgum) and many tropical species, annual growth rings are not easily recognized.

children.label: earlywood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed during the early part of the growing season. It is usually less dense and weaker mechanically than latewood.

children.label: latewood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed after the earlywood formation has ceased. It is usually denser and stronger mechanically than earlywood.

children.label: reaction wood
children.definition: Wood with more or less distinctive anatomical characters, formed typically in parts of leaning or crooked stems and in branches. In hardwoods, this consists of tension wood, and in softwoods, compression wood.

children.label: tension wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood found in leaning trees of some hardwood species and characterized by the presence of gelatinous fibers and excessive longitudinal shrinkage. Tension wood may cause warping.

children.label: compression wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood formed on the lower side of branches and inclined trunks of softwood trees. Compression wood shrinks excessively longitudinally, compared with normal wood.

children.label: heartwood
children.definition: The wood extending from the pith to the sapwood, the cells of which no longer participate in the life processes of the tree. Heartwood may contain phenolic compounds, gums, resins, and other materials that usually make it darker and more decay resistant than sapwood.

children.label: juvenile wood
children.definition: Inner core of xylem surrounding the pith. The cells are smaller and less structurally developed than those of the outer xylem. The time during which juvenile wood is formed is termed the juvenile phase.

children.label: sapwood
children.definition: The wood of pale color near the outside of the log. Under most conditions, the sapwood is more susceptible to decay than heartwood.

children.label: tyloses
children.definition: Masses of parenchyma cells appearing somewhat like froth in the pores of some hardwoods, notably the white oaks and black locust. Tyloses are formed by the extension of the cell wall of the living cells surrounding vessels of hardwood.

children.label: seeds
children.definition: A plant structure that develops from an ovule and has as parts an embryo enclosed in a seed coat.

children.label: recalcitrant seeds
children.definition: Seeds that do not acquire desiccation tolerance during their development and are shed at relatively high moisture contents. These seeds rapidly loose water and their viability.

children.label: pseudocereals
children.definition: Pseudocereals are fruits or seeds of non-grass or non-cereal plants and are consumed in same way as cereal grains. They are typically gluten-free, high in proteins and nutrients.

children.label: seed coat
children.definition: Protective outer covering or coverings of a seed formed from the integuments of the ovule.

children.label: tegmen
children.definition: A thin inner seed coat of seeds present in some seeds.

children.label: aril
children.definition: A special, usually fleshy seed covering of certain seeds that commonly develops from the ovule integument(s) or seed stalk (funiculus, raphe, etc.). It partially or completely surrounds the seed of some plants.

children.label: testa
children.definition: The outer coat of the seed derived from the integument(s).

children.label: epicotyls
children.definition: The portion of the axis of an embryo or young seedling above the point where the cotyledon(s) is attached.

children.label: hypocotyls
children.definition: The part of an embryo or seedling below the cotyledon(s) and above the radicle (but sometimes including it).

children.label: cotyledons
children.definition: A part of the embryo in a seed plant. The number of cotyledons is an important feature in classifying plants. In seeds without an endosperm, they store food which is used in germination. In some plants, they emerge above the soil surface and become the first photosynthetic leaves.

children.label: endosperm
children.definition: Nutritive tissue of the seeds of flowering plants that surrounds the embryos. It is produced by a parallel process of fertilization in which a second male gamete from the pollen grain fuses with two female nuclei within the embryo sac. The endosperm varies in ploidy and contains reserves of starch, oils, and proteins, making it an important source of human nutrition.

children.label: sporangia
children.definition: A hollow, unicellular or multicellular saclike, spore-producing structure.

children.label: parenchyma (plant tissue)
children.definition: Short cells having simple pits and functioning primarily in the metabolism and storage of plant food materials. They remain alive longer than the tracheids, fibers, and vessel elements, sometimes for many years. Two kinds of parenchyma cells are recognized—those in vertical strands, known more specifically as axial parenchyma, and those in horizontal series in the rays, known as ray parenchyma.

children.label: aerenchyma
children.definition: Prominent intercellular or gas spaces present in the cortical tissues of leaves, roots and stems of aquatic and some other plants, which facilitate gaseous exchanges between the root and the shoot.

children.label: sclerenchyma
children.definition: A protective or supporting tissue in higher plants composed of cells with walls thickened and lignified and often mineralized.

children.label: sclereids
children.definition: A type of sclerenchyma cell which is various in shape (e.g., isodiametric, branched, star-shaped, etc.) and characteristically has cell walls which are pitted, thick, and lignified. Sclereids, like fiber cells, occur in many parts of the plant and povide structural support to plant tissues.

children.label: fiber cells
children.definition: A sclerenchyma cell which is narrowly elongated with pointed ends and has thickened secondary cells walls. Fiber cells, like sclereids, may contain lignin, provide structural support to plant tissues, and may be found in various parts of the plant.

children.label: meristems
children.definition: A group of plant cells that are capable of dividing infinitely and whose main function is the production of new growth at the growing tip of a root or stem.

children.label: cambium
children.definition: A thin layer of tissue between the bark and wood that repeatedly subdivides to form new wood and bark cells.

children.label: xylem
children.definition: A vascular plant tissue that conducts water and minerals salts from the roots to the leaves.

children.label: growth rings
children.definition: The layer of wood growth put on a tree during a single growing season. In the temperate zone, the annual growth rings of many species (e.g., oaks and pines) are readily distinguished because of the differences in the cells formed during the early and late parts of the season. In some temperate zone species (e.g., black gum and sweetgum) and many tropical species, annual growth rings are not easily recognized.

children.label: earlywood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed during the early part of the growing season. It is usually less dense and weaker mechanically than latewood.

children.label: latewood
children.definition: The portion of the growth ring that is formed after the earlywood formation has ceased. It is usually denser and stronger mechanically than earlywood.

children.label: reaction wood
children.definition: Wood with more or less distinctive anatomical characters, formed typically in parts of leaning or crooked stems and in branches. In hardwoods, this consists of tension wood, and in softwoods, compression wood.

children.label: tension wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood found in leaning trees of some hardwood species and characterized by the presence of gelatinous fibers and excessive longitudinal shrinkage. Tension wood may cause warping.

children.label: compression wood
children.definition: Abnormal wood formed on the lower side of branches and inclined trunks of softwood trees. Compression wood shrinks excessively longitudinally, compared with normal wood.

children.label: heartwood
children.definition: The wood extending from the pith to the sapwood, the cells of which no longer participate in the life processes of the tree. Heartwood may contain phenolic compounds, gums, resins, and other materials that usually make it darker and more decay resistant than sapwood.

children.label: juvenile wood
children.definition: Inner core of xylem surrounding the pith. The cells are smaller and less structurally developed than those of the outer xylem. The time during which juvenile wood is formed is termed the juvenile phase.

children.label: sapwood
children.definition: The wood of pale color near the outside of the log. Under most conditions, the sapwood is more susceptible to decay than heartwood.

children.label: tyloses
children.definition: Masses of parenchyma cells appearing somewhat like froth in the pores of some hardwoods, notably the white oaks and black locust. Tyloses are formed by the extension of the cell wall of the living cells surrounding vessels of hardwood.

children.label: xylem vessels
children.definition: Wood cells in hardwoods of comparatively large diameter that have open ends and are set one above the other to form continuous tubes called vessels. The openings of the vessels on the surface of a piece of wood are usually referred to as pores.

children.label: tracheids
children.definition: Tracheids are elongated cells in the xylem, which conduct water and mineral salts in plants. Sometimes referred to as fibers, tracheids are more abundant and longer in length in softwoods than hardwoods. The longer length of softwood tracheids is significant to paper manufacture.

children.label: phloem
children.definition: The tissues of the inner bark, characterized by the presence of sieve tubes and serving for the transport of elaborate foodstuffs.

children.label: sap
children.definition: A fluid that circulates in vessel elements (xylem) or sieve tube elements (phloem) of a plant. It is often noticed as an exudate from the ruptured plant tissues. It is composed of water, salts, sugars, gases, organic matter, etc.

children.label: cutin
children.definition: A waxy hydrophobic substance deposited on the suface of plants, composed of complex long chain fatty esters and other fatty acid derivatives. This polymer is a major constituent of the plant cuticle.

children.label: adventitious buds
children.definition: A subnormal bud that develops at any place on plant part but not at nodes, usually when a plant part is injured or cut off.

children.label: pedicel
children.definition: In an inflorescence consisting of more than one flower, the foot- stalk or stem of an individual flower or fruit.

children.label: palynology
children.definition: The branch of science in studying spores and pollen.

children.label: melissopalynology
children.definition: Analysis of pollen grains present in honey.

children.label: forensic palynology
children.definition: The study of pollens, spores or related material found in forensic samples to solve legal issues.

children.label: paleobotany
children.definition: Branch of paleontology concerned with the study of fossil plants and plant life in the geologic past.

children.label: ethnobotany
children.definition: The study of plant lore and agricultural customs of a people. In the fields of ethnomedicine and ethnopharmacology, the emphasis is on traditional medicine and the existence and medicinal uses of plants and plant extracts and their constituents, both historically and in modern times.

children.label: chaff
children.definition: Seed coverings separated from cereal grains after threshing, together with other stem or leaf debris from the process.
